title: RS20702
content: The Water Resources Development Act of 2000 authorized federal agencies to participate in Everglades restoration projects under the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan. Changes in water quantity and quality since the 1950s have significantly impacted the region's ecology, leading to water shortages during the dry season. The Everglades, a vital component of the South Florida ecosystem, faces challenges in meeting freshwater demands for both natural systems and human consumption. Water shortages in Florida are expected to increase due to rising urban and agricultural demand. The Everglades, once a vast network of wetlands, acted as natural filters and recharge areas for aquifers. However, development efforts in the mid-1800s altered the hydrology of the Everglades, impacting its ecological balance. The Everglades' abundant moisture, rich soils, and subtropical temperatures supported a vast array of species. However, by the mid-1800s, development efforts altered the hydrology, leading to flood control and reclamation projects. The Central and Southern Florida project significantly changed the water regime, directing water into canals and rivers instead of flowing naturally across the Everglades. The Everglades ecosystem has been significantly impacted by the Central and Southern Florida project, leading to changes in water flow patterns. This alteration, combined with urban and agricultural development, has reduced the Everglades to half its original size, threatening plant and animal species. Pollution from urban areas and agricultural runoff has further harmed the ecosystem, causing a decline in native vegetation and an overabundance of invasive species. These changes have disrupted the equilibrium of coastal estuaries and reef systems. The Everglades ecosystem has been impacted by pollution from urban areas and agricultural runoff, leading to a decline in native vegetation and an overabundance of invasive species. Restoration activities, coordinated by the South Florida Ecosystem Restoration Task Force, aim to address these issues with a focus on restoring natural habitats and species, improving water quality, and achieving compatibility between built and natural systems. The estimated cost for achieving these goals in South Florida is nearly $20 billion, with a significant portion allocated to the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP) to "get the water right" and restore natural hydrologic functions. The Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP) aims to restore natural hydrologic functions and water quality in South Florida with an estimated cost of nearly $20 billion. CERP focuses on capturing and storing freshwater for use during the dry season, directing 80% to the natural system and 20% for agricultural and urban consumption. It involves removing levees and canals, building reservoirs, storage wells, and pumping stations to replicate natural flow.
